Award.AwardTitle: QuBBD: Collaborative Research: Personalized Predictive Neuromarkers for Stress-Related Health Risks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Coronary heart disease (CHD) remains the leading cause of premature death among adults in the U.S. and other postindustrial nations. Predicting CHD risk - especially for a particular individual - remains a fundamental challenge. This project will investigate the application of statistical machine learning approaches to multimodal brain imaging, behavioral, biological, and related data to enhance the prediction of CHD risk. It specifically addresses the question of whether particular patterns of human brain activity during psychological stress reliably predict known risk markers of CHD; namely, stress-related rises in blood pressure and arterial morphology. From a basic science perspective, this research will advance our mechanistic understanding of how the brain relates to our physical health. From a public health perspective, this research will help to identify markers of brain activity that could be objectively identified and possibly targeted for modification in otherwise healthy people at risk for future CHD.

The key challenge with mapping neuroimaging data to CHD risk lies in being able to very precisely regress observed psychological stress reactions on the time-series of brain activity recorded in thousands of voxels, and identify which brain regions are most relevant for the regression. Conventional analytic approaches involve forming coarse temporal summaries by committing to specific parametric models, such as a generalized linear model and a fixed model for hemodynamic response, that result in poor accuracy. This award supports initiation of a collaborative research project that brings together a highly cross-disciplinary team of statistical machine learning, neuroimaging and health psychology researchers to tackle the following two goals: 1) identify a generalizable model and neuromarkers that predict individual differences in cardiovascular risk factors based on neural dynamics under psychological stress. This will be enabled through novel methods for functions-to-real and functions-to-function lasso regression; 2) characterize how neural patterns can be integrated with other physiological and anthropometric factors to personalize individual risk scores and neuro-biomarkers. This award is supported by the National Institutes of Health Big Data to Knowledge (BD2K) Initiative in partnership with the National Science Foundation Division of Mathematical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate whether brain response to stress can be predictive of a person's risk of heart disease. More specifically, the project focused on building a cross-validated predictive model of stress-induced blood pressure changes from whole-brain hemodynamic activity as recorded by fMRI scans when the subjects were performing two established stress tasks. The degree of stress-evoked brain activity was quantified at each voxel and for each subject using a univariate GLM. These voxel wise measures of stress-evoked hemodynamic activity were assessed during two tasks (Stroop, Multisource Interference Task; MSIT). Each task had a Congruent (Con; easy) and Incongruent (Inc; stressful) manipulation and the Inc-Con contrast on every voxel was used as a feature to predict individual differences in reactivity of systolic blood pressure under stress.

This is an ultra-high dimensional problem as the number of subjects (n=310) is much smaller than the number of features per subject (p = 207,684 voxels). We developed a pipeline that combines two methods for dealing with high dimensional datasets. First, the dimensionality of the predictor variables (i.e., voxels) was reduced using singular value decomposition (SVD). This reduced the feature space to 310 components. Since this results in a high dimensional problem (i.e., n = p), we used a shrinkage model (e.g., LASSO, elastic net) to select the subset of components that best predicted blood pressure reactivity.

The model was trained on a subset of the sample (Training Sample) in order to identify the most predictive components. Once the best-fit model was identified, the model was projected back into voxel space by inverting the SVD solution. This produces a whole-brain voxel map of loadings (i.e., a neuromarker) of the best predictive model of blood pressure reactivity from whole-brain fMRI activity. Finally, the efficiency of this voxel map was validated on the hold out data (Test Sample) by taking the dot product of the stress-evoked hemodynamic responses for each subject and the neuromarker map. Validity of this model was assessed by looking at the correlation between predicted blood pressure reactivity and observed reactivity. Across hold out test validations, this combination of dimensionality reduction (PCA) and shrinkage model (elastic net) resulted in an average correlation between observed and predicted BP reactivity of r=0.30, with upper and lower bounds on the 95% confidence interval of 0.104 and 0.489 respectively.

This predictive model was able to reliably capture a subset of the variance in blood pressure reactivity from the functional neural data (8.97% of the variance). Thus, this proof of concept analysis shows that it is possible to reliably build biomarkers from whole-brain neuroimaging datasets. However, it should be noted that valid predictions only emerge when the dimensionality reduction step is applied to the data first. When this step is removed, and modern high-dimensional regression methods such as LASSO or elastic net is applied directly to the voxel data, the test validation accuracy plummets to chance or worse. Furthermore, nonlinear methods and methods that take into account the entire time series of brain activity did not improve accuracy, with or without dimensionality reduction step, due to the low signal-to-noise ratio in this problem. Thus predictive models need to account for the correlational structure of neuroimaging datasets when learning to map between neural features and low signal output variables such as "soft" health outcomes (BP changes).

To conclude, the study contributes evidence that it is possible to understand the role of the brain in determining "soft" health outcomes while most studies focus on using the brain response to either decode the input stimuli or predict a diseased state (like presence or absence of a brain disease) only.
